description.narrative: The overall project objective is a democratic community where youth participate in community governance and collaborate with local authorities and leaders for their own development. It is noted in the context and problem analysis that young people who constitute over 60% of the population in Zimbabwe have been alienated from participation in national and local political processes despite opportunities offered by democratic spaces that exist in the communities. The main outcomes include: 1: Enhanced knowledge of rights and responsibilities amongst youths and duty bearers in Matobo 2:  Improved abilities of youth to define the problems they face within their communities, finding solutions and positively influencing community development plans 3: Increased youth representation and participation in local governance structures and 4: YETT has the capacity to advocate and influence key actors on issues of youth participation at local and national levels. The rights holders for this project mainly include young men and women who are being excluded from decision making processes at local and national levels. The community level activities will be implemented in 4 wards of Matobo rural districts in Matabeleland South province. The main strategy includes empowerment of youth on their rights and responsibilities and advocacy on issues affecting youth, inclduing influencing decsion makers. YETT’s theory of change is that if YETT builds the capacity of youths (rights holders) to know their rights and organise themselves in order to claim those rights, provides platforms for policy dialogue and engagement between young people and duty bearers and to influence policy and development processes and advocates for an enabling environment for youth development then there will be increased youth participation in national development and empowerment in Zimbabwe.
This project mainly contributes to results within Democratic culture. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020
